def by_length(arr):
    """
    Given an array of integers, sort the integers that are between 1 and 9 inclusive,
    reverse the resulting array, and then replace each digit by its corresponding name from
    "One", "Two", "Three", "Four", "Five", "Six", "Seven", "Eight", "Nine".

    For example:
      arr = [2, 1, 1, 4, 5, 8, 2, 3]   
            -> sort arr -> [1, 1, 2, 2, 3, 4, 5, 8] 
            -> reverse arr -> [8, 5, 4, 3, 2, 2, 1, 1]
      return ["Eight", "Five", "Four", "Three", "Two", "Two", "One", "One"]
    
      If the array is empty, return an empty array:
      arr = []
      return []
    
      If the array has any strange number ignore it:
      arr = [1, -1 , 55] 
            -> sort arr -> [-1, 1, 55]
            -> reverse arr -> [55, 1, -1]
      return = ['One']
    """"""

That is a neat function. If you want to learn how to implement that in C, I recommend the book _Learning C the Hard Way_ [1] (The HARD Way is one of the most well-known tutorials for learning C).
[1]:

Definitely one of the best introductions to C I've seen.
I did a long (by my standards) stint in the C world back in the 90s, and I would not have been able to do it without a book like this.

At a certain point, one just needs to sit down and write the code for something like this. For me, there's a sort of eureka moment when the code is finally written.
I would _never_ have thought to write a function like this. But, by the time I was done, it made perfect sense.

I think that's the point of this tutorial - it shows you the right way of doing things, and then by doing it yourself, you learn the right way, and understand it.

This is a good example of a fundamental problem with teaching beginners how to program.
Even if you are an expert in the language, it's not necessarily easy to write this function

    return arr.sort()

It might be possible to do something more clever using a real sorting algorithm like radix sort. But radix sort isn't stable, so it can be dangerous to use it unless you know what you're doing.

It's also possible to use an existing module to do the sorting. The cmath module in Python includes both a stable sort and a radix sort.

In addition to sorting algorithms, there are also algorithms to count the occurrences of each digit in an array.

 Counting sort
 Radix sort

I hate this guy's style. He's using classes for everything and I'm pretty sure that's not what python is for.

Since the objective is to learn python, that doesn't matter. You could just as well learn how to use classes, dictionaries, etc.

If you want to learn python, I'd just use it as it's meant to be used. There's a lot of code out there that will just confuse the hell out of a beginner.

Indeed, but this isn't for beginners.

Python has a lot of syntactic sugar that makes things like this pretty easy to write, but a lot of people have problems with it.
I'm not sure it's the best way to get people into Python.

I don't agree. Python is very easy to read, in my opinion, and this is a good example of the power of Python. It's a good way to show how easy it is to combine different operations in a single line of code.

def by_length(arr):
    """
    Given an array of integers, sort the integers that are between 1 and 9 inclusive,
    reverse the resulting array, and then replace each digit by its corresponding name from
    "One", "Two", "Three", "Four", "Five", "Six", "Seven", "Eight", "Nine".

    For example:
      arr = [2, 1, 1, 4, 5, 8, 2, 3]   
            -> sort arr -> [1, 1, 2, 2, 3, 4, 5, 8] 
            -> reverse arr -> [8, 5, 4, 3, 2, 2, 1, 1]
      return ["Eight", "Five", "Four", "Three", "Two", "Two", "One", "One"]
    
      If the array is empty, return an empty array:
      arr = []
      return []
    
      If the array has any strange number ignore it:

            -> reverse arr -> [55, 1, -1]
      return = ['One']
    """"""
    return ''.join(map(ord, by_length(arr)))

This program is a variation on the classic algorithm for computing nth number in a sequence.  The idea is to "bucket brigade" the numbers in the sequence.  Since all the numbers in a sequence are less than n, you can start with n+1 empty buckets and fill them in order.  To find the nth number, just skip over the empty buckets in the output.

This is an extremely naive implementation of the algorithm. For one thing, you are sorting and then reversing an entire array, instead of just the relevant sub-array.

Your method will work when the array is small enough to fit in memory and all digits are smaller than the largest digit in the array. The point is that when you have an array of digits greater than 9, you can't sort the array and you can't reverse it.

And the largest number in the array is 18. So the sort and reverse work fine. What they don't do is return an array of all the digits, as the original poster requested.

Perhaps I wasn't clear. This implementation _will_ work, but it will fail to return all the digits, which is the point of the original algorithm.

It looks like a joke from this point of view.

Well, you can return more than one value from a function, you just have to have an explicit return statement for each one. It's the same as returning a tuple in C.</s>

      return ["Eight", "Five", "Four", "Three", "Two", "Two", "One", "One"]
    
      If the array is empty, return an empty array:
      arr = []
      return []
    
      If the array has any strange number ignore it:

            -> reverse arr -> [55, 1, -1]
      return = ['One']

    def get_digits(arr):
    """
    Return a list of strings with the digits in order.

    The order is from "One", "Two", "Three", "Four", "Five", "Six", "Seven", "Eight",
    "Nine".
    If the array is empty, return an empty list.
    """
    arr.sort()
    return [x for x in range(0, len(arr)-1) if x not in arr]

return get_digits(arr)

This is a naive implementation which returns only the first nine digits (digits 0–9). A more complicated implementation could return the full sixteen digits (digits 0–9 and A–F).

Wow, the difference between the Python and C++ versions of this function is really interesting. The C++ version has a lot of boilerplate, but is obviously much more efficient.

If you look at the Python version, you'll see it's not actually a version of the function at all: it's a function _wrapper_ around the C++ version.
The Python version _is_ much more efficient than the C++ version, but only because the Python version is basically free to generate any code it wants, and so can make much more efficient use of the underlying C++ function.
The Python version is equivalent to something like this:

def by_length(arr):
    """
    Given an array of integers, sort the integers that are between 1 and 9 inclusive,
    reverse the resulting array, and then replace each digit by its corresponding name from
    "One", "Two", "Three", "Four", "Five", "Six", "Seven", "Eight", "Nine".

    For example:
      arr = [2, 1, 1, 4, 5, 8, 2, 3]   
            -> sort arr -> [1, 1, 2, 2, 3, 4, 5, 8] 
            -> reverse arr -> [8, 5, 4, 3, 2, 2, 1, 1]
      return ["Eight", "Five", "Four", "Three", "Two", "Two", "One", "One"]
    
      If the array is empty, return an empty array:
      arr = []
      return []
    
      If the array has any strange number ignore it:
      arr = [1, -1 , 55] 
            -> sort arr -> [-1, 1, 55]
            -> reverse arr -> [55, 1, -1]
      return = ['One']
    """"""

This is a classic example of a problem which requires an algorithm instead of a function.
For one thing, your function does nothing useful if passed an empty array.
For another thing, the algorithm you have written is very naive.  It relies on a very difficult assumption: that every number will occur once.  If your input is [1,2,3,4,5], for example, you will get [1,1,1,1,1,1,1] back.  The algorithm will not sort the numbers or reverse them.

I think your algorithm will also fail if the array is sorted. It might be better to return a tuple like (1,2,3,4,5,8,9).

Using (1,2,3,4,5,8,9) would be incorrect since you'd be returning an array of tuples, which is not what is required.

What is required is that each number (except for zero) appears once. The easiest way to do this is to return an array of tuples.</s>

Another way to do it is to use sort_keys() instead of sort() and then reverse().

Even better would be a single `reverse()`.

If you're in Python, and don't want to use `reverse`, you can do:
sorted_values = sorted(values)
return sorted_values[1:9]

If you want to do it without reversing the list, there are a few ways to go about it:
* Use the [range(1, 10) for x in xrange(1, 10)] syntax.
* Use map(lambda x: x, values). This returns a tuple.
* Use map(lambda x: x[1:9], values). This returns a dictionary.

I'm not too familiar with Python, but in Perl, if you don't want to reverse the list, this can be done with the map function:
map { $_->[1..9] } values;

No, this is a great example because it shows the sort of critical thinking that you need to do when you start to write your own programs. The question is how to solve a problem. The answer is there is no right answer, because it depends on what you are trying to achieve, how the problem is framed, and what you already know.
As such, it's the kind of question that is worth asking, especially if the answer is "use this library".
The world needs more people that know how to break down a problem and find the right solution for them, rather than looking for someone else to do it for them.

This is a typical problem that arises while programming: how to sort an array of numbers (or strings, or whatever) in a desired order. The task is even more difficult if the items need to be sorted by multiple criteria. The simple solution is to sort the array and then to select the items from the array in a specified order. The problem is that we may need to repeat the sorting and the selecting for each item. This is where the solution given by  comes in handy. This function sorts an array of integers between 1 and 9 inclusive, sorts the resulting array, and then reverses the array. The result is the sorted array with the items in the desired order.

The idea of the above solution is to split the problem in two parts. The first part sorts the items. The second part selects the items in the correct order.

The sorting algorithm is straightforward and is given as an example in the introduction section of the article. The sorting function returns the sorted array. It is then used in the selection part.

The selection part is based on a simple idea. Given the sorted array, simply iterate over the items, and select the items with a given index that is less than the current index by one. This is

I've been reading about it for a few days. Here's what I think I understand:
Some mathematical operations (like sorting) can be expressed as a function that operates on a list of numbers.
One of those functions is called "map" which, when applied to a list, gives you a new list where every item is the result of applying the function to every item in the original list. So, in this case, when you call map on the original list, you get back a new list of numbers where every item in the original list has been sorted.
The next function is "filter", which takes a function and an input and returns true if the input is in the function's domain. In other words, it returns true if the input satisfies the requirements for the function.
So, now we have a list of numbers. The only requirement for map is that all the items in the list are numbers.
Filter takes a function, and a list of numbers. If a number is in the function's domain, the function returns true

"Array comprehensions are preferred over dictionary comprehensions since they are more flexible."
How so?

You can do dictionary comprehensions with arrays:
[x for x in sorted(list)]
and with lists:
[y for y in sorted(list)]
and of course, you can do a combination of both:
[x for x in [list[:len(list)]]]
This is not possible with dictionary comprehensions.
